Article Title: Apple says it has removed viral dating apps Tea and TeaOnHer from App Store; says: Developers failed to ...
Article Text:
Apple's Secret 3-Year Plan: A New iPhone Era is Coming!

What made Tea and TeaOnHer dating apps controversial





Two controversial dating safety apps, Tea and TeaOnHer, have been pulled from the Apple App Store following violations of Apple ‚Äôs guidelines on content moderation and user privacy. The removal, first reported by app store intelligence provider Appfigures, occurred earlier this week across all markets. Apple confirmed to TechCrunch that the apps were removed due to non-compliance with App Review Guidelines 1.2, 5.1.2, and 5.6, which address user-generated content moderation, unauthorized sharing of personal information, and excessive user complaints.Both apps, however, remain available on Google Play Store According to an Apple representative, the apps failed to address concerns raised by the company, including reports of minors‚Äô personal information being shared. Negative user reviews and complaints further contributed to the decision. The developers of Tea and TeaOnHer have not yet responded to requests for comment.Tea, launched in 2023 and gaining viral attention in 2025, marketed itself as a safety tool for women, allowing users to share details about men on dating apps, including personal information, reviews, and ‚Äúgreen flag‚Äù or ‚Äúred flag‚Äù labels, similar to the ‚ÄúAre We Dating the Same Guy?‚Äù Facebook groups.However, the app faced backlash from men who argued it violated their privacy and raised defamation concerns. Over the summer, Tea suffered a significant data breach, exposing 72,000 images, including 3,000 selfies and photo IDs used for account verification, as well as 59,000 images from posts and messages.TeaOnHer, a rival app launched to allow men to review women similarly, also faced scrutiny after TechCrunch reported security flaws in August that exposed users‚Äô personal data, including government IDs and selfies. According to Appfigures, Tea recorded 6.1 million lifetime downloads and $5 million in gross revenue, while TeaOnHer saw 2.2 million downloads without in-app purchases. Despite their removal from the App Store, copycat apps are gaining traction. Notably, TeaOnHer and Him ‚Äì Overheard has climbed from No. 90 to No. 27 on the Overall Top App Charts, with 354,000 downloads.As the apps remain live on Google Play, questions linger about their future and the broader implications for user privacy and safety in dating app ecosystems.
Article Summary: Tea and TeaOnHer dating apps have been removed from the Apple App Store. Apple says the apps violated guidelines on content moderation and user privacy. Both apps remain available on Google Play Store, where copycat apps are gaining traction. The developers of the apps have not yet responded to requests for comment.

Article Title: Reddit sues Perplexity; lawsuit says: Is stealing data that Perplexity "desperately needs" to ...
Article Text:
Perplexity AI browser and email assistant

What Perplexity said on Reddit's lawsuit





Lawsuits against AI chabot companies have been piling up. Latest to face legal trouble is Perplexity. On Wednesday, October 22, social media giant Reddit filed a lawsuit in New York federal court against artificial intelligence startup Perplexity and three data-scraping companies: Lithuania-based Oxylabs, Russia-based AWMProxy, and Texas-based SerpApi. In its complaint, Reddit claims that these companies unlawfully scraped Reddit‚Äôs data to train Perplexity‚Äôs AI-powered ‚Äúanswer engine,‚Äù. Reddit said that the data-scraping companies circumvented its data protection measures to steal data that Perplexity "desperately needs" to power its "answer engine" system.The lawsuit against Reddit is part of a growing wave of legal challenges by content owners against tech companies, accusing them of misusing copyrighted material to train AI systems.Reddit, known for its vast network of interest-based ‚Äúsubreddit‚Äù communities, claims its platform is the most frequently cited source for AI-generated responses to user queries. The company accuses Perplexity of collaborating with at least one of the named data-scraping firms to access billions of search results without permission, despite lacking a license to use Reddit‚Äôs content. Reddit has previously licensed its data to companies like Google and OpenAI for AI training purposes.The lawsuit follows a similar legal action Reddit initiated against AI startup Anthropic in June, which remains ongoing. Reddit‚Äôs chief legal officer, Ben Lee, described the case as part of a broader issue, stating, ‚ÄúAI companies are locked in an arms race for quality human content‚Äîand that pressure has fueled an industrial-scale ‚Äòdata laundering‚Äô economy.‚ÄùReddit alleges it sent Perplexity a cease-and-desist letter last year, after which Perplexity reportedly increased its citations to Reddit content ‚Äúforty-fold.‚Äù The company is now seeking unspecified monetary damages and a court order to prevent Perplexity from using its dataIn response, Perplexity defended its practices. In a statement, the company said, ‚ÄúOur approach remains principled and responsible as we provide factual answers with accurate AI, and we will not tolerate threats against openness and the public interest.‚Äù
Article Summary: Reddit files lawsuit against AI startup Perplexity and three data-scraping companies. The social media giant claims these companies unlawfully scraped Reddit‚Äôs data. The lawsuit is part of a growing wave of legal challenges by content owners against tech companies.

Article Text:
AI-generated image for representation





Australia has reportedly launched an investigation into the safety practice of several artificial intelligence (AI) chatbot companies, asking them to explain how they prevent minors from being exposed to harmful or sexual content. According to a Reuters report, the country‚Äôs eSafety Commissioner has sent notice to Character Technologies, owner of celebrity simulation chatbot tool character.ai, and rivals Glimpse.AI, Chai Research and Chub AI demanding explanations of their content filters, child protection systems and moderation processes.The regulator, as per the report, said that the step was necessary amid rising fears that unregulated AI chatbots could expose young users to sexual conversations or promote self-harm.The Reuters report quotes Commissioner Julie Inman Grant said in the statement: ‚ÄúThere can be a darker side to some of these services, with many ... chatbots capable of engaging in sexually explicit conversations with minors,‚Äù adding ‚ÄúConcerns have been raised that they may also encourage suicide, self-harm and disordered eating.‚ÄùThe order comes under Australia‚Äôs strict online safety framework, which allows the regulator to compel companies to reveal their safety measures or face fines of up to A$825,000 (about $536,000) per day.Character.ai, one of the largest AI chatbot platforms, is already facing a lawsuit in the U.S. after the mother of a teenager alleged that her son took his own life following repeated chats with an AI companion. The company has said it has since introduced safety alerts that link users expressing suicidal thoughts to mental health hotlines.The eSafety office said it has received reports from schools suggesting that some students spend up to five hours a day chatting with AI bots ‚Äî in some cases about sexual topics. Experts warn that such prolonged exposure can lead to emotional dependency or risky behavior among children.According to Reuters, OpenAI ‚Äî the creator of ChatGPT ‚Äî has not been included in this round of inquiries because Australia‚Äôs current safety code applies only to AI chatbots designed for companionship or role-play. ChatGPT will fall under the same regulatory framework from March 2026.From December, social media companies in Australia will be required to block or delete accounts belonging to users under 16 years of age or face a fine of up to A$49.5 million ‚Äì part of the government‚Äôs broader push to safeguard young people's mental and physical health.
Article Summary: Australia has reportedly launched an investigation into the safety practice of several artificial intelligence (AI) chatbot companies. The country‚Äôs eSafety Commissioner has sent notice to Character Technologies, Glimpse.AI, Chai Research and Chub AI demanding explanations of their content filters. The regulator, as per the report, said that the step was necessary amid rising fears that unregulated AI chatbots could expose young users to sexual conversations or promote self-harm.

Article Title: Britain joins US, Europe and Japan in declaring Apple and Google smartphone dominance: What this means for tech giants and their response

YouTube states that the feature is "beginning to roll out" today, so it may take some time to become available for all mobile users.The company also plans to expand this feature to parental controls ‚Äúlater this year,‚Äù where these limit notifications for children will be non-dismissible, offering a more proactive approach to managing kids' screen time.Notably, this new functionality mirrors similar optional screen time limits offered by other social media platforms like Instagram. The Verge reports that TikTok also offers the same feature and is the only platform that currently extends this feature to web users as well.

Article Title: Tesla board chairman calls proxy advisory firm‚Äôs criticism of Elon Musk‚Äôs $1 trillion pay ‚Äòmisguided recommendations‚Äô; writes open letter to shareholders
Article Text:
Here‚Äôs the full letter shared by Tesla board chairman

Dear Fellow Shareholders,

Following recent misguided recommendations from ISS and Glass Lewis regarding Proposals 1, 3 and 4, I want to set the record straight on the reelection of our directors and Elon‚Äôs equity incentives.

At Tesla, we would rather design visionary systems than be constrained by what‚Äôs conventional. We are not afraid to break the mold and we build things the right way. In contrast, ISS and Glass Lewis evaluate all companies and all proposals using the same simplistic, one-size-fits-all framework.

They are fundamentally unable to evaluate companies, like Tesla, that chart their own course and challenge the status quo. Thankfully our shareholders have ignored their recommendations ‚Äì otherwise, you may have missed out on our market capitalization soaring 20x while the proxy advisors time and time again recommended ‚Äúagainst‚Äù Tesla proposals designed to promote the sort of extraordinary growth we have enjoyed.

I encourage you to ignore ISS‚Äôs and Glass Lewis‚Äôs advice for this year‚Äôs Annual Meeting and vote with the Board‚Äôs recommendations on all proposals. Let me address some of the key misconceptions reflected in ISS‚Äôs and Glass Lewis‚Äôs recommendations.

But you‚Äôre giving him too much money!

Elon gets nothing unless shareholders enjoy exceptional investment returns. The 2025 CEO

Performance Award

was designed with one overarching purpose: to supercharge Tesla‚Äôs next phase of exceptional growth, innovation and value creation.

There are no layups, and Elon only gets additional voting rights if he delivers on bold market capitalization and operational goals. Furthermore, he only gets to keep those voting rights and obtain the associated economic benefits if he leads Tesla for at least 7.5 more years.

This plan delivers enormous upside to shareholders, who will receive approximately nine-tenths of the value created. To put it into perspective, even if Elon only hits the first milestone, he will be delivering approximately a trillion dollars of sustained value to shareholders, almost doubling our current market capitalization, far exceeding any payout to Elon for achieving that tranche.

In other words: this performance incentive award is generally contingent on delivering products that support Elon‚Äôs vision for Sustainable Abundance, addresses shareholder concerns regarding retention and long-term succession, and ultimately creates extraordinary shareholder value. There is no guaranteed pay because we believe the key to Tesla‚Äôs long-term success lies in ensuring alignment of our CEO‚Äôs interests with those of our shareholders.

But you‚Äôre going to cause too much dilution!

Shareholders should consider this award to be an investment; not dilution. If the full 2025 CEO Performance Award vests at the highest market capitalization milestone, Tesla‚Äôs market capitalization would experience a 7.5x increase in value in exchange for 13.12% dilution by the proxy advisors‚Äô highest estimate.

The proxy advisors‚Äô preoccupation with dilution misses the point that the pie must increase by more than seven-fold to get there. In contrast to ISS‚Äôs and Glass Lewis‚Äôs rigid views of the world ‚Äì which sees shareholders as ‚Äúgiving away value‚Äù ‚Äì those of us on the Board believe in a reality where every shareholder gets a bigger slice of the growing pie. While I don‚Äôt agree with many statements in the proxy advisors‚Äô reports, I agree with ISS‚Äôs acknowledgement that our 2025 CEO Performance Award is designed so that ‚Äúhistorical value would be realized not only for Musk, but also for the company's shareholders.‚Äù

But the product goals are way too easy!

There are no ‚Äúeasy‚Äù milestones under the 2025 CEO Performance Award. To achieve the final Adjusted EBITDA milestone, Elon will need to lead Tesla to $400 billion in Adjusted EBITDA ‚Äì which means growing our current Adjusted EBITDA by ~26x.

This award aims to see Tesla grow larger than any company in history. Each and every operational milestone, including the product goals, must be validated by an extraordinarily ambitious ‚Äì and sustained ‚Äì increase in market capitalization. Market capitalization ‚Äì the market‚Äôs verdict on real value ‚Äì can‚Äôt be ‚Äúgamed‚Äù through aggressive pricing or other tactics to create illusory growth; Tesla‚Äôs market capitalization targets require profitable, real-world products.

If Elon doesn‚Äôt deliver sustained increases in market capitalization to validate the success of any product goal, he will earn nothing under such product goal.

You didn‚Äôt need to do this to keep Elon. What he really wants is votes!

The 2025 CEO Performance Award channels Elon‚Äôs desire for a stable ownership structure to promote extraordinary growth into what shareholders actually care about: sustained, long-term value creation.

While the Special Committee evaluated designing a high-vote structure, it wasn‚Äôt feasible under current rules. Instead, the 2025 CEO Performance Award improves upon the wildly successful 2018 CEO Performance Award by separating voting power from economic value to strengthen alignment among Elon, Tesla and shareholders and promotes longer term retention by delaying vesting of any earned share for at least 7.5 years.

Voting rights on a tranche are only earned after shareholders win ‚Äì and win big.

But your governance for compensation is flawed!

The disinterested Special Committee undertook a seven-month long process to design and negotiate the 2025 CEO Performance Award and Special Share Reserve under the A&R 2019 Equity Incentive Plan. Most importantly, even following that rigorous process shareholders still have the final say.

Governance is not an end in and of itself, but a necessary ingredient for durable, long-term value creation. We judge governance by results, and Tesla‚Äôs stock has delivered annualized returns of almost 50% since the beginning of 2018, far outpacing the broader market.

While ISS and Glass Lewis would prefer that we follow the herd and apply their cookie-cutter guidelines, it is precisely Tesla‚Äôs ability to lead, innovate and think independently that has enabled such extraordinary shareholder returns.

And your directors are bad at governance!

Our longest standing independent director, Ira, is uniquely qualified to serve on our board and lead our governance efforts, having received numerous awards in the corporate governance and growth company spaces. While Ira has been guiding our governance and compensation, total shareholder returns have topped 39,000%.

As Tesla continues to grow shareholder value through technological progress, Kathleen‚Äôs decades of legal and operating experience and compensation, human capital and management knowledge will be crucial for Tesla to win the AI talent war.

To be a great director at Tesla, there‚Äôs no question that you must have thick skin. As a trailblazing company willing to break the mold in pursuit of an extraordinary future, it‚Äôs no surprise that our directors are easy targets. Despite this, our directors have consistently demonstrated their integrity and risen above the criticisms of those too narrow-minded to appreciate our ambitious vision.

The fact is both Ira and Kathleen are widely recognized as corporate governance leaders because they remain passionately focused on our mission to create Sustainable Abundance for all. They have the fortitude to do the right thing ‚Äì which is often the hard thing ‚Äì by prioritizing shareholders‚Äô long-term interests rather than caving to short-term desires in support of the whims of critics.

Tesla designs and builds robots, but we don‚Äôt let robots design our governance structure as ISS and Glass Lewis would prefer. That is why we have assembled a Board with a wide array of perspectives, from people with varied experiences. In contrast to the formulaic approach reflected in ISS‚Äôs and Glass Lewis‚Äôs recommendations on our directors and Proposals 3 and 4, we on the Tesla Board don‚Äôt see governance as a one-size-fits-all exercise.

We view governance as a dynamic process, where we act with transparency and integrity as all of our directors work together to deliver financial value to our shareholders. The way we practice governance demands bold, deliberative and thought-provoking leadership as we face new challenges, navigate new paths, and ultimately drive Tesla into an exciting future with Sustainable Abundance for all. Our more thoughtful governance process requires dedication and contributions from incredible directors like Ira, Kathleen and Joe.

So, in evaluating these recommendations from ISS and Glass Lewis, as well as any third-party advice regarding your vote at this year‚Äôs Annual Meeting, we encourage you ‚Äì shareholders who have made an actual financial investment in Tesla‚Äôs future ‚Äì to make your own decision rather than following proxy advisors who don‚Äôt own a single share of Tesla stock.

I think it is noteworthy that ISS and Glass Lewis have both announced plans to update their product offerings, with Glass Lewis admitting that ‚Äúthe traditional one-size-fits-all model of proxy advice no longer meets the needs of a diverse client base.‚Äù So, their models are changing, just not today, and not for our Annual Meeting. Well, at Tesla, we know that progress waits for no one and speed is crucial to success.

While the proxy advisors tinker with their models, I urge you to take back your vote.

If you prefer that Tesla turn into just another car company mired in the ways of the past, then you should follow ISS and Glass Lewis. If you believe that Tesla, under the visionary leadership of Elon and the oversight of a Board that includes business leaders with integrity like Ira, Kathleen and Joe, then you should vote with Tesla.

Thank you for your continued support of Tesla.

Very truly yours,

Robyn Denholm

Chairperson of the Board





Tesla board chairperson Robyn Denholm has written an open letter to shareholders describing proxy advisory firms ‚Äì ISS and Glass Lewis‚Äô criticism of Elon Musk ‚Äôs pay package as ‚Äòmisguided recommendations‚Äô. Shared by Tesla on X, the letter says that these companies are ‚Äúfundamentally unable to evaluate companies, like Tesla, that chart their own course and challenge the status quo. ‚Äù Denholm urged shareholders to ignore ISS‚Äôs and Glass Lewis‚Äôs advice for this year‚Äôs Annual Meeting which is scheduled for November 8.In the letter, he clarifies that Musk‚Äôs $1 trillion pay is a ‚Äòperformance incentive award‚Äô which is ‚Äúcontingent on delivering products that support Elon‚Äôs vision for Sustainable Abundance, addresses shareholder concerns regarding retention and long-term succession, and ultimately creates extraordinary shareholder value.‚Äù
Article Summary: The Tesla board chairman shared the full letter shared by ISS and Glass Lewis. The 2025 CEO Performance Award was designed with one overarching purpose: to supercharge Tesla‚Äôs next phase of exceptional growth, innovation and value creation. Elon only gets additional voting rights if he delivers on bold market capitalization and operational goals. The award aims to see Tesla grow larger than any company in history.

Article Title: Why Europe's fight with Chinese chip company Nexperia has 'worried' GM, Honda, Volkswagen and other auto companies
Article Text:
Nvidia H20 Chips for China: What‚Äôs Really Going On?

GM, Volkswagen and others issue 'disruption' warning

'Nexperia chip stocks may last only weeks', warns European Automobile Manufacturers‚Äô Association





China‚Äôs new export restrictions on automotive chips and components, prompted by the Dutch government‚Äôs takeover of Chinese-owned chipmaker Nexperia, have left global auto companies including GM, Honda, Volkswagen and others 'shocked' and 'anxious'. According to a report by Nikkei Asia, the tension between Netherland government and China over Nexperia are roiling the global automotive supply chain, escalating tensions in the tech rivalry between China and Europe.The turmoil stems from the Netherlands‚Äô invocation of its Goods Availability Act to intervene in Nexperia‚Äôs operations, citing ‚Äúserious governance shortcomings.‚Äù Nexperia, based in Nijmegen and acquired by Shanghai-listed Wingtech Technology in 2019, faced scrutiny after Dutch Economic Affairs Minister Vincent Karremans informed Parliament on October 14, 2025, that the company‚Äôs role in the Dutch and European semiconductor ecosystem posed ‚Äúgreat economic security importance. ‚Äù In apparent retaliation, Beijing barred Nexperia‚Äôs China arm and its subcontractors from exporting specific components and sub-assemblies made in China.General Motors CEO Mary Barra warned during the company‚Äôs quarterly earnings call on October 21, 2025, that Beijing‚Äôs curbs on certain chips could disrupt production. ‚ÄúWe have an internal team working around the clock with our supply chain partners to minimize possible disruptions,‚Äù Barra told Nikkei Asia, describing the situation as ‚Äúvery fluid‚Äù and promising further updates.He highlighted issues including the ‚Äúimproper transfer‚Äù of production capacity, financial resources, and intellectual property to a foreign entity linked to Nexperia‚Äôs CEO, Zhang Xuezheng, who was subsequently suspended as a director and removed as CEO.The impact extends beyond GM. Simon Schutz of the German Association of the Automotive Industry (VDA) noted on October 21, 2025, that Nexperia, a key supplier of semiconductors for vehicle electronics, informed German automakers and suppliers on October 10 that it could not guarantee chip supplies. ‚ÄúThe situation could soon lead to significant production restrictions‚Äîor even a stop in production‚Äîif the interruption of Nexperia chip deliveries cannot be resolved in the short term,‚Äù Schutz warned, adding that the VDA is collaborating with companies, the German government, and the European Commission to find solutions.German auto giant Volkswagen warned of temporary production outages citing China‚Äôs export restrictions on semiconductors made by Nexperia. A spokesperson for Volkswagen told CNBC by email that while Nexperia is not a direct supplier of the company, some Nexperia parts are used in its vehicle components, which are supplied by Volkswagen‚Äôs direct suppliers. ‚ÄúWe are in close contact with all relevant stakeholders in light of the current situation to identify potential risks at an early stage and to be able to make decisions regarding any necessary measures,‚Äù a Volkswagen spokesperson said. ‚ÄúHowever, given the evolving circumstances, short-term effects on production cannot be ruled out,‚Äù they added.The European Automobile Manufacturers‚Äô Association (ACEA) cautioned that Nexperia chip stocks may last only weeks, with sourcing alternatives potentially taking months. ‚ÄúWe suddenly find ourselves in this alarming situation,‚Äù said ACEA Director General Sigrid de Vries, noting the issue affects numerous suppliers and most ACEA members.Nexperia‚Äôs October 9 notice to Japanese clients, seen by Nikkei Asia, flagged potential supply disruptions as a force majeure event. Honda Motor told Nikkei it is assessing impacts, as some of its components use Nexperia chips, though production remains unaffected so far. Meanwhile, a Japanese semiconductor distributor reported a fivefold surge in orders for chips from other manufacturers, like Texas Instruments, while another is negotiating switches to alternative suppliers.
Article Summary: China‚Äôs new export restrictions on automotive chips and components have left global auto companies'shocked' and 'anxious' The tension between Netherland government and China over Nexperia are roiling the global automotive supply chain, escalating tensions in the tech rivalry between China and Europe.

Article Title: How Google Doodle is celebrating quadratic equations
Article Text:
What the Doodle shows

Why Google chose the quadratic equation





A quick refresher: the formula that changed maths







Beyond the formula: Google‚Äôs educational mission

Why it matters





The quadratic equation has found a new place to shine, right on Google ‚Äôs homepage. The tech giant‚Äôs latest animated Doodle turns the world‚Äôs most famous search engine into a playful classroom, celebrating the formula ax¬≤ + bx + c = 0 that has challenged and fascinated generations of students. The Doodle, which first appeared in the US and UK, is now rolling out across Europe, the Middle East, and Africa. Timed with the academic calendar, it aims to remind students, teachers, and curious adults alike that maths can be visual, interactive, and even fun. By blending art, education, and technology, Google is turning a simple search into an opportunity to learn.The animation begins with the familiar Google logo transforming into an elegant visual of parabolas, each representing the curve of a quadratic equation. The Doodle highlights the key components of the formula, the coefficients a, b, and c, and demonstrates how these numbers affect the shape and position of the curve. In a few seconds, it shows how the equation‚Äôs roots, or solutions, are found where the curve crosses the x-axis.This is more than a nostalgic nod to school maths. The Doodle serves as a quick refresher for anyone who might have forgotten how the quadratic formula works.With its engaging movement and simple explanations, it captures the beauty of algebra in motion, making complex concepts feel approachable.Google‚Äôs timing is intentional. Around October and November, many education systems worldwide cover quadratic equations as part of the curriculum. Search data shows a clear trend: global queries for ‚Äúhow to solve quadratic equations‚Äù rise sharply during this period.By featuring the formula in a Doodle, Google not only celebrates a core mathematical concept but also supports students as midterm exams approach. The Doodle links directly to Google‚Äôs learning resources, including Search features that allow users to type, scan, or even speak equations. From there, they can get step-by-step explanations, interactive graphs, and practice problems generated in real time.In doing so, Google turns its homepage into a study companion. What might look like a cute animation is actually a digital bridge between curiosity and comprehension.The quadratic formula,x = [-b ¬± ‚àö(b¬≤ ‚àí 4ac)] / (2a),is one of the most recognisable equations in mathematics. It solves any second-degree polynomial equation, offering a precise way to find the values of x that make the expression equal zero.At the heart of this formula is the discriminant (Œî = b¬≤ ‚àí 4ac), which determines the number and type of solutions.If Œî > 0, there are two real roots.If Œî = 0, there is one repeated real root.If Œî < 0, the roots are complex (non-real).This principle is far from abstract. Quadratic equations describe real-world phenomena everywhere: in physics (projectile motion), engineering (parabolic reflectors), economics (profit maximisation), and even computer graphics. By visualising this concept in the Doodle, Google connects the dots between theory and reality.Google has increasingly positioned itself as a learning ally. Over the past few years, it has introduced AI-driven study aids, practice modules, and interactive learning cards directly within Search. Students can scan handwritten equations with their phones and instantly receive step-by-step solutions and visual explanations.This quadratic Doodle builds on that mission, showing how technology can make education more inclusive.Instead of treating maths as intimidating, it reframes it as something dynamic and discoverable. It also aligns with Google‚Äôs larger goal of supporting STEM education globally, especially in regions where access to quality learning resources can be limited.The quadratic equation is more than just another topic in the syllabus. It represents a key transition point for students, from simple arithmetic to higher-level reasoning. Mastering it lays the foundation for understanding calculus, data analysis, and scientific modelling.By choosing this equation for a Doodle, Google reminds users that maths is not only relevant but also beautiful in its logic and structure. For many, this simple animation may spark curiosity, confidence, or even nostalgia.While the Doodle will only appear for a day, its impact may last much longer. It encourages learners to revisit one of mathematics‚Äô most powerful tools and shows that with the right mix of creativity and technology, even an equation can inspire millions.In the end, Google‚Äôs Doodle is not just a celebration of the quadratic equation. It is a celebration of learning itself, proof that curiosity and discovery can still begin with a simple search.

Article Title: Godfather of AI Geoffrey Hinton, Prince Harry, Meghan Markle, and 800+ scientists, celebrities sign open letter against OpenAI, Meta's superintelligent AI mission
Article Text:

Public opposes AI race, polling reveals

Tech giants race ahead despite safety concerns







Over 800 prominent figures spanning technology, politics, entertainment and science have signed an extraordinary open letter demanding an immediate halt to superintelligent AI research. The coalition, announced by the Future of Life Institute, includes AI godfather Geoffrey Hinton, Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak, Britain's Prince Harry and Meghan Markle , and former Trump strategist Steve Bannon. Five Nobel laureates, ex-military leaders, and celebrities like Joseph Gordon-Levitt and will.i.am have also lent their names to the cause.Their message is simple: "a prohibition on the development of superintelligence" until there is "broad scientific consensus that it will be done safely and controllably" and "strong public buy-in." Superintelligence refers to AI systems that would exceed human intelligence at all cognitive tasks‚Äîtechnology that organizers believe could arrive in as little as one to two years."The future of AI should serve humanity, not replace it," Prince Harry said in his statement. "The true test of progress will be not how fast we move, but how wisely we steer."Actor Joseph Gordon-Levitt offered a more pointed critique: "Yeah, we want specific AI tools that can help cure diseases, strengthen national security, etc.But does AI also need to imitate humans, groom our kids, turn us all into slop junkies and make zillions of dollars serving ads? Most people don't want that."The timing reflects mounting alarm that superintelligence‚ÄîAI surpassing human capability across all cognitive tasks‚Äîcould arrive within one to two years. Yet polling released with the letter shows a stunning disconnect: 64% of Americans believe such systems shouldn't be built until proven safe, while just 5% support the current breakneck pace of development.Anthony Aguirre, the institute's executive director, argues that "a small number of very wealthy companies" are choosing humanity's path forward without consulting anyone else. "No one's really asked almost anybody else, 'Is this what we want?'" he told TIME.The appeal comes as Silicon Valley's biggest players accelerate their pursuit of artificial general intelligence and beyond. Meta's Mark Zuckerberg declared superintelligence "now in sight" last July. OpenAI CEO Sam Altman expects it by 2030. Companies are pouring hundreds of billions into AI infrastructure this year alone.Even one OpenAI employee, Leo Gao, broke ranks to sign‚Äîa notable defection from a company Altman calls a "superintelligence research company."The statement represents the Future of Life Institute's second major intervention. A 2023 letter calling for a six-month AI pause failed to slow development, prompting this more focused campaign targeting superintelligence specifically.
Article Summary: Over 800 prominent figures have signed an open letter demanding an immediate halt to superintelligent AI research. The coalition includes AI godfather Geoffrey Hinton, Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak, Britain's Prince Harry and Meghan Markle.

As debates around screen time and its impact on children continue to grow, Sundar Pichai , CEO of Google, presents a balanced and considered approach. He recognises that technology is an inevitable part of modern life, offering both opportunities and challenges, and believes that teaching children to manage their own screen time is far more effective than outright bans.Rather than avoiding technology, he encourages open dialogue, setting realistic boundaries, encouraging curiosity, and modelling healthy behaviour. Pichai‚Äôs parenting philosophy highlights a broader trend among tech leaders: encouraging mindful engagement, instilling self-regulation, nurturing critical thinking, and helping children develop healthy, lifelong habits in a highly connected and digital-first environment.Sundar Pichai admitted that he has ‚Äúalways been worried about technology‚Äù in relation to his children. However, he recognises that growing up in a digital era is unavoidable. Unlike some peers in the tech industry who impose rigid rules, Pichai focuses on equipping children with the knowledge and skills to manage their own screen time. He emphasises teaching children to take ownership of their choices, enabling them to navigate technology responsibly rather than seeing it as forbidden or dangerous.Pichai‚Äôs philosophy is rooted in the belief that digital literacy is essential for today‚Äôs youth. He explains, ‚ÄúRather than just banning devices, it‚Äôs important they learn to make choices.‚Äù By learning to self-regulate, children acquire critical thinking skills and the ability to differentiate between productive and mindless digital engagement. All reflect the belief that technology should be treated as a tool to enhance life, rather than as a default source of entertainment or distraction.For Pichai, the lessons are clear: fostering digital literacy, creating small barriers to discourage mindless consumption, and modelling responsible use can be more effective than imposing outright bans. In an era where technology permeates every aspect of life, cultivating responsible screen habits equips the next generation to thrive, making conscious choices while still enjoying the opportunities technology provides.

The audio, Popelka said, was so realistic that even she couldn‚Äôt distinguish it from her real voice.The revelation comes as governments and corporations scramble to counter a surge in AI-driven impersonation fraud, where cloned voices, faces, or emails are used to breach security systems, steal data, or manipulate decisions.Speaking at The Times UK Tech Summit in London, Popelka described how the fake message appeared authentic and well-timed. China's recent expansion of rare Earth export controls appeared to intensify the US-China trade war, but some analysts point out that the dispute began with an action taken by America in late September. According to a report in the South China Morning Post, the decision by the US Bureau of Industry and Security (US-BIS) to widen its trade Blacklists in September angered China, leading to a slew of retaliatory measures against the US. This included action against US chip giant Qualcomm.On September 29, the US Bureau of Industry and Security broadened its trade blacklists that reportedly prompted not only China‚Äôs retaliatory measures but also influencing the Netherlands‚Äô seizure of chip firm Nexperia.The BIS oversees two blacklists -- the entity list and the military end-user list -- targeting companies deemed security threats. Previously, US exporters needed licenses to deal with listed entities. The new rules, effective late September, extend restrictions to any company at least 50% owned by listed entities.On September 29, the US Commerce Department issued a new rule expanding its restricted export list, known as the Entity List, to automatically include subsidiaries owned 50% or more by a company on the list, according to posting in the US Federal Register.The action is said to have greatly increased the number of companies that require licenses to receive American goods and services. The rule is likely to disrupt supply chains. It also makes it more difficult for companies to determine whether exports to a customer or supplier are restricted, and places more of a burden on the exporter to figure out ownership before moving forward.Though companies around the world are on the Entity List, the change will most significantly impact Chinese entities, experts said.America puts companies on the Entity Blacklists that it has determined pose risks to US national security or foreign policy. There are reportedly about 1,100 Chinese entities on the list, according to think tank the Center for a New American Security.China's Commerce Ministry strongly criticized the rule. "This move by the U.S. is extremely egregious in nature," the ministry said in a statement. "It seriously infringes upon the legitimate rights and interests of the affected enterprises, severely disrupts international economic and trade order and gravely undermines the security and stability of global industrial and supply chains."In SCMP report, Goldman Sachs analysts noted that, while the US rule applies globally, China views it as a targeted escalation.Earlier this month, Dutch government believed chipmaker Nexperia‚Äôs Chinese owners planned to move its manufacturing operations to China, prompting the unprecedented seizure of the company. Authorities seized control of Nexperia‚Äôs management and ousted its Chinese CEO, Zhang Xuezheng, citing national security concerns.
Article Summary: China's recent expansion of rare Earth export controls appeared to intensify the US-China trade war. Some analysts point out that the dispute began with an action taken by America in late September. On September 29, the US Bureau of Industry and Security broadened its trade blacklists. This reportedly prompted not only China‚Äôs retaliatory measures but also influencing the Netherlands‚Äô seizure of chip firm Nexperia.

Airbnb CEO Brian Chesky stated that the company typically does not use OpenAI 's latest models extensively in production for its AI tools. He noted that there are often faster, cheaper alternatives available. Recently, the travel app maker announced that it has updated its in-app artificial intelligence customer service agent, which was rolled out to all US users in English in May. The update allows customers to take more actions without needing a live representative. In an interview, Chesky revealed that the agent is built on 13 different AI models, sourced from providers including OpenAI, Alibaba Group Holding Ltd.'s Qwen model, Alphabet Inc.‚Äôs Google , and other open-source providers.Chesky said to Bloomberg:He specifically praised the Alibaba model, saying,Airbnb's new AI-powered customer service agent now includes action buttons and links that allow users to handle tasks such as changing or cancelling reservations on their own.This update has resulted in a 15% decrease in users requiring help from a live representative and reduced the average resolution time from nearly three hours to six seconds. The company also plans to introduce Spanish and French language support later this year, followed by 56 additional languages next year.Apart from the AI agent, Airbnb has also introduced new social features aimed at helping users connect and enhancing travel recommendations within the app. Guests can now share their Airbnb profiles with others after booking an experience, and travellers who joined the same tour can message each other. However, conversations continue only if the recipient accepts the message request.More features are planned for next year, and Chesky said these could eventually support user-generated content on the platform.Chesky also noted that he has decided not to integrate the company‚Äôs app with OpenAI‚Äôs ChatGPT because the platform‚Äôs tools aren‚Äôtyet. He added that Airbnb will continue to monitor the development of ChatGPT‚Äôs app integrations and could consider collaborating in the future, similar to other travel platforms such as Booking Holdings and Expedia Group.Chesky said, explaining that because Airbnb is a community of verified users, OpenAI would need to build a platform strong enough for Airbnb‚Äôs app to function in anway within ChatGPT, the report noted.Chesky, who is friends with OpenAI CEO Sam Altman , said he has even advised the company on its new third-party developer features.
